title: Measuring Bone Remodeling and Recreating the Tumor-Bone Microenvironment Using Calvaria Co-culture and Histomorphometry
procedures:
All mice used in these assays were obtained from BALB/c mice strains, using male and female mice indiscriminately. Previous culture experiments have also been performed using other strains, such as FVB, Swiss mice, CD-1, and CsA mice11,12,14. All mice were housed according to National Institutes of Health (NIH) guidelines, Appendix Q. Procedures involving animal subjects have been approved by the Institutional Animals Care and Use Committee (IACUC) at the Center for Scientific Research and Higher Education at Ensenada (CICESE).
1. Calvarial dissection
Sterilize dissection instruments (e.g., 1 x 2 teeth tissue forceps, straight surgical scissors, dissecting scissors, fine-tipped tweezers, fine curved tip dissecting forceps, dissecting forceps, scalpel). Sterile distilled water can be used to clean the surgical tools between each dissection, and sterile 1x PBS can be used for cleaning each hemi-calvaria.
Place the sterile dissection instruments, water, 1x PBS, and required materials to carry out the procedure (e.g., micropipettes, precipitate glasses, sterile Petri dishes) in a laminar flow hood.
	NOTE: Carry out the entire procedure under sterile conditions.
Add 12 mL of sterile 1x PBS into two 10 cm Petri dishes.
Select the pups and place them near the hood.
	NOTE: Dissect the calvarias from 5-7 day old pups.
Pick and hold the mouse carefully using dissecting forceps.
Decapitate the mouse using dissecting scissors and place the head in a Petri dish with PBS.
	NOTE: Decapitation is not suitable for older mice. If the experiment must be done with older mice, the method of euthanasia should be modified according to the animal experimentation rules.
Hold the head firmly by the nose area with 1 x 2 teeth tissue forceps and remove the skin over the skull until the calvaria is visible.
Identify the sutures (i.e., sagittal, coronal, and lambdoid) of the skull on the exposed calvaria.

Penetrate with the tip of the microscissors approximately 2 mm behind the lambdoid suture and make a straight cut alongside it.
Insert the tip of the microscissors on the rear side of the skull. Make a straight cut along the distal side of the lambdoid suture towards the coronal suture. Proceed similarly with the other lambdoid suture.
Make another cut (at a 45° angle) to connect the end of the cut made with the cut of the anterior fontanel.
Repeat steps 1.10 and 1.11 with the other lambdoid suture.
	NOTE: It is important to identify the sutures to make appropriate cuts and to be able to perform adequate embedding and data analysis.
Use fine-tip forceps to remove the calvaria and place it in a Petri dish. With a scalpel, make a straight cut from the posterior fontanel along the sagittal suture through the coronal suture and ending in the anterior fontanel to obtain two hemi-calvarias.
Pick up each of the hemi-calvarias with the fine-tipped tweezers and place them in a new Petri dish containing PBS.
2. Calvaria culture
Add 1 mL of high-glucose DMEM medium supplemented with 0.1% bovine serum albumin (BSA) and 1% antibiotic/antimycotic (i.e., penicillin and streptomycin) in the wells of a 24 well plate. With fine-tip forceps, pick up each hemi-calvaria and place it in a well.
	NOTE: Put the hemi-calvarias concave side down.
Incubate the hemi-calvarias for 24 h at 37 °C with 5% CO2.
Remove the culture medium from each well and add 1 mL of fresh media containing the compound to test or conditioned media from other cells.
	NOTE: Use at least three hemi-calvarias for each treatment group and use negative and positive controls.
Incubate the hemi-calvarias for 7 days, changing the media every 2-3 days.
3. Culture with cancer cells

Select a Petri dish with cancer cells at 80-90% confluence and trypsinize them. To trypsinize, wash the cancer cells 1x using PBS (5 mL per 75 cm2 flask) followed by incubation in an HBSS solution containing 0.05% trypsin and 0.53 mM EDTA (2 mL per 75 cm2 flask).
Transfer the cell suspension into a 15 mL conical tube and centrifuge at 800 x g for 5 min at room temperature (RT).
Remove and discard the supernatant.
Resuspend the pellet in 2 mL of DMEM containing 2% fetal bovine serum (FBS) and 1% antibiotic/antimycotic. Count live cells.
Assign hemi-calvarias to each study group (i.e., the negative control and coculture group for RNA or histology analysis).
Remove the culture media from the hemi-calvarias and add 1 mL of DMEM containing 2% FBS and 1% antibiotic/antimycotic supplemented or not supplemented with cancer cells.
	NOTE: The amount of cells to add can change depending on the cell line tested. With cancer cells like MDA-MB-231 or PC-3, 500,000 cells per well work appropriately.
Incubate for 24 h at 37 °C with 5% CO2. Pass each hemi-calvaria to a new well to retain only cancer cells that adhered to the bone tissue.
Incubate for 7 days at 37 °C with 5% CO2 and change the media every 2-3 days.
4. Fixation
Cut squares of tissue paper to wrap the hemi-calvarias.
	NOTE: Biopsy foam pads or steel capsules for small biopsies can also be used.
Use straight fine-tip forceps to pick up each hemi-calvaria from the sagittal suture, place on a tissue paper, and wrap.
Place the wrapped hemi-calvaria inside a labeled embedding cassette.
Place the cassette into a container with 10% phosphate-buffered formalin.
Fix for 24 h at 4 °C.
5. Decalcification

Remove the formalin, add 1x PBS, and agitate the tissues for 30 min to rinse the hemi-calvarias.
Remove the PBS and add 10% EDTA (pH = 8, 0.34 M).
	NOTE: Verify that the solution covers the tissues completely.
Decalcify the tissues for 48 h at 4 °C.
Discard the EDTA solution and add 1x PBS to rinse the tissue.
Store the hemi-calvarias in 70% ethanol until the histology processing.
6. Tissue processing
Dehydrate the tissues with rounds of 96% ethanol, 60 min (3x), followed by 100% ethanol, 60 min (3x).
Replace the ethanol by 100% xylene, 60 min (3x).
Incubate the cassettes in paraffin wax, 60 min (2x).
7. Embedding
Open the cassettes, carefully remove the tissue paper, and unwrap the calvaria.
Pick up each calvaria carefully and stack all the hemi-calvarias from the same group in the same orientation.
Put some paraffin in a mold.
Pick up all hemi-calvarias with the forceps and place them inside the mold with the sagittal suture down towards the base of the mold.
	NOTE: Orientation of the hemi-calvarias in the mold during inclusion is crucial to obtain consistent histological sections and reproducible results because this orientation will allow posterior identification of the front and parietal bones from the calvarias and the coronal suture facilitating the quantitative assessment.
Release the forceps and verify that the hemi-calvarias stay in place.
Place the labeled cassette on top of the mold and fill it with more paraffin to cover the hemi-calvarias.
Move the molds to the cold surface.
8. Sectioning
Trim 500-600 µm of the sagittal suture with the microtome.
Cut 4 µm thick sections, and collect the sections needed.
Trim another 300 µm.
Cut and collect another six 4 µm thick sections.
Trim the block 300 µm further and collect more sections.

Mount the sections onto glass microscope slides.
Dry the slides at RT.
9. Staining
Immerse the sections in 100% xylene for 3 min.
Submerge in 100% ethanol for 1 min.
Merge in 96% ethanol for 1 min.
Immerse in 80% ethanol for 1 min.
Submerge in 70% ethanol for 1 min.
Rinse in water for 3 min.
Submerge in hematoxylin for 3 min.
Rinse in water until the section is clear.
Submerge in a saturated lithium carbonate solution for 10 sec.
Rinse in water for 3 min.
Submerge in 96% ethanol for 1 min.
Submerge in eosin for 3 min.
Immerse in 96% ethanol for 1 min.
Submerge in 100% ethanol for 1 min.
Submerge in 100% xylene for 3 min.
Add some per mount-mounting medium to the slide and protect it with a coverslip.
	NOTE: You can complement the hematoxyline and eosin (H&E) staining with tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) staining to evaluate osteoclast and osteolysis.
10. Quantitative assessment: defining area for analysis
Examine the sections under low power (i.e., 4x) to identify the orientation and the sutures.
Define the coronal suture and identify the long bone surface on one side and the short surface on the other.
Identify the coronal suture under 40x magnification, and move two or three optical fields away from the suture along the long surface. Capture images of this area for analysis.
Define the old bone area and the new bone area. The eosin Y with orange G stains the old bone darker and the new bone lighter.
Measure the total bone area of the old and new bone with Image J software using the color threshold tool. Express the results as µm2.
11. Data analysis

Analyze the results using statistical software. Significant differences between groups can be determined using appropriate tests (e.g., nonparametric Mann-Whitney U test as is done herel).
